speaker: grahampaige
content: Welcome everyone. Let's begin discussion on: Agenda Item No. 3.5: Curriculum Update - The board will consider adoption of a new mathematics curriculum for grades 6–8, aligned with updated state standards. The proposed curriculum includes digital resources, project-based learning activities, and teacher training components. Adoption is intended to improve student outcomes in algebra readiness and standardized test performance.. Who would like to start?

speaker: kateacuff
content: I'll go first. Thank you, Graham Paige. So we've had this math program under review since last year. What specific changes do these materials offer over what our teachers have been using currently? And how does it address those persistent achievement gaps between subgroups within each grade level? Can someone walk me through some examples from sixth-grade lessons specifically?

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Kate, thank you for your thoughtful questions. As chair of the curriculum committee, I'd be happy to provide more insight into the updates. From my understanding, one significant change is the incorporation of real-world applications and problem-solving exercises, which should help students see the relevance of mathematical concepts beyond just formulas and procedures. For instance, in sixth grade, there's an entire unit dedicated to data analysis and graphing, where students learn to interpret charts and graphs related to climate change – something they can really connect with.

Regarding subgroup disparities, the new curriculum places greater emphasis on differentiated instruction strategies, including technology-enhanced tools designed to support English language learners and special education students. Our instructional coaches will receive targeted professional development to ensure effective implementation across all classrooms.

speaker: kateacuff
content: Ellen Osborne, thanks so much for providing context around differentiation techniques. That sounds promising. However, could Dr. Rodriguez clarify whether any additional staff positions were budgeted alongside this proposal to guarantee adequate coaching capacity at every middle school site? We know firsthand about existing workload concerns among current instructional coaches. How confident are we that their plates won't get even fuller without commensurate staffing increases?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Ms. Cuff brought up great points regarding both the need for extra funding but also making sure that we're supporting our educators who already feel overwhelmed. It seems reasonable given everything going on right now. If we don't make adjustments accordingly, then maybe we shouldn't move forward until such time when we actually put forth effort towards addressing educator burnout. Does anybody want to comment further before moving onto public comments?

speaker: davidoberg
content: I think Katrina makes valid arguments here. In terms of ensuring proper rollout, let’s discuss potential timelines if indeed we decide to adopt this revised curriculum package today. Are we looking at summer PD sessions exclusively focused on implementing this material effectively? Or perhaps phasing-in certain aspects during next academic year while still allowing instructors flexibility amid ongoing pandemic-related challenges? Some clarity on logistics might alleviate anxieties surrounding coach workloads.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Thanks David O'berg. To answer his question directly, yes, part of the plan involves offering optional intensive workshops throughout July and August focusing primarily on content delivery methods tailored toward differentiating instruction better suited to meet diverse needs. Additionally, we propose dedicating two full days early September solely centered upon lesson planning collaboration amongst colleagues sharing similar subject areas. This way, by working together ahead of fall semester kick-off, teachers gain familiarity navigating software platforms embedded inside the chosen textbook series along with peer-to-peer guidance setting them up well for success once classes resume post-Labor Day weekend.

speaker: davidoberg
content: Jon Noel Carro, appreciate the detailed response. Two follow-up queries though: Firstly, considering many families face financial constraints limiting access to reliable internet connectivity outside regular classroom hours, did the district explore alternative arrangements enabling equal opportunities for remote participation come workshop season? Secondly, has administration considered incentivizing instructor attendance via stipends tied explicitly to successful completion of said trainings rather than relying purely voluntary engagement?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Mr. O'Berg raises excellent considerations again! On point number one, absolutely; equity was top-of-mind. District officials worked closely with local community organizations securing commitments for free Wi-Fi hotspots near libraries plus partnering schools hosting after-school computer labs open late evenings twice weekly starting mid-July onward. These measures aim squarely at bridging home-accessibility divides faced particularly hard-hit neighborhoods. Second item regards incentives—yes, discussions took place exploring possible compensation models linked tightly to completed coursework milestones. While nothing concrete yet exists officially attached to upcoming summer events per se, rest assured conversations continue actively evaluating ways best recognizing valuable contributions made voluntarily thus far.

speaker: davidoberg
content: Well, kudos to us for proactively tackling accessibility issues head-on. Now, turning attention back to actual curricular substance itself—I'm curious, Dr. Rodriguez mentioned earlier incorporating'real world application.' Could somebody elaborate exactly what types of projects kids may engage in, say, seventh graders studying geometry? Would love hearing tangible illustrations demonstrating precisely why adopting this particular resource bundle stands poised to elevate overall educational experiences.

speaker: judyle
content: Hi everybody. Building off Dave's inquiry, I too am interested in seeing practical manifestations of'real-world applications'. Specifically concerning eighth-graders delving deeper into pre-algebraic thinking patterns... Perhaps Ellen or another team expert could share sample assignments illustrating connections drawn between abstract ideas & everyday life scenarios? Something relatable enough for young minds grasping advanced notions.

speaker: kateacuff
content: Judy Le, couldn’t agree more - would like to hear specifics behind'real-life connection claims', especially algebraically speaking. One example provided dealt with environmental topics. But surely other subjects exist showcasing applicability elsewhere. The sooner we grasp tangibles driving student motivation levels higher, the faster buy-ins happen organically.

speaker: judyle
content: Absolutely, Kate. What resonates most powerfully with me is how these updated materials seem primed to ignite curiosity within each learner. Take fractions, for instance. Imagine having eighth-grade students tackle case studies involving fair distribution practices employed globally amidst food banks serving underprivileged communities. By doing math 'in service,' it transcends mere calculations becoming meaningful actions positively impacting lives close-by. Can someone walk us through examples akin to those woven seamlessly into revamped lessons plans?

speaker: ellenosborne
content:
Thank you, Katrincallsen, Davidoberg, and others for your thoughtful questions. Regarding additional staff positions, I can assure you that we have taken into account the importance of sufficient coaching capacities across all middle school sites. Our proposed budget does include provisions for hiring three new instructional coaches specifically dedicated to support teacher professional development and implementation of differentiated instruction strategies.

While acknowledging existing workload concerns, we believe investing in targeted training programs will ultimately benefit our educators in managing their responsibilities efficiently. Moreover, built-in check-points throughout the roll-out process allow us to reassess and adjust resources according to emerging needs.

Regarding timeline and logistical details, I defer to Director Jon Noel Carro's comprehensive explanation covering summer workshops, collaborative lesson-planning activities, and flexible

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: That sounds good. So thank you very much for answering my previous query about whether there were any changes since last week because no one had reached out saying they wanted anything changed so therefore none existed. And just real quick, I know people talked about wanting some kind of incentive structure around attending these things over the summer which I guess isn't necessarily finalized either. Is that correct?

speaker: davidoberg
content: It seems clear from various comments shared tonight that everyone acknowledges both merits alongside legitimate apprehensions regarding this proposal. As an educator myself prior entering public office, empathize deeply w/colleagues facing added burdens potentially stemming from such significant shifts. Yet simultaneously recognize compelling reasons supporting adoption given its promise elevating learning outcomes long-term. With respect towards differing perspectives voiced, suggest tabling final decision until May meeting when hopefully further refinements addressing key sticking points emerge. Then collectively assess feasibility based on progress updates presented then. Does anybody second motion table discussion till later date?

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ok, that's enough, we will now vote privately.  We are voting on Agenda Item No. 3.5: Should the district adopt the proposed new mathematics curriculum for grades 6–8?.  If each of you could please record your vote in the chat, I will tally them up and announce the results.

speaker: kateacuff
content: Yes

speaker: ellenosborne
content: Abstain

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Abstaining due to insufficient information currently available.

speaker: davidoberg
content: Yes

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Yes
